home-page.p: I’m a tinkerer who uses electronic and electromechanical components to create bizarre and hopefully interesting installations and devices. I call it “Theatronics”: electronics with a theatrical twist. Examples of these can be found on the Erik’s Theatronics website.

Over the years, I’ve acquired a large number of electronic components, mostly through the acquisition of secondhand batches of parts. There have been so many of them that I’ve lost track a bit, hence this website. It also allows me to find additional information, such as datasheets, more easily.
There are so many now that I will probably never be able to use them all in my lifetime. I also don’t have an application for all components (I work more with digital than analogue).

p.b: Therefore, if you see something interesting or just want a few components for a very small price, let me know.

home-page.p: Of course, there may be additional packaging and shipping costs. I won’t sell all, but most of it is for sale. And that would do me a favor too: I’d rather have things used than left lying around in my shed!

about-page.p: The component-inventory website is a completely static website (so no cookies!). It is built with XML technology, using XProc and XSLT to generate all the HTML pages. Parts are built with technology developed within my company Xatapult. Generating the full website from its XML sources takes less than 10 seconds.

As far as I know, all additional information on this website, like datasheets, is public and not copyright protected. If I have accidentally violated anyone’s intellectual property, please let me know.

The source code and data for this website is hosted on Github. Everything is published under the GNU General Public License, giving you complete freedom to copy, share, reuse, or modify it to your heart’s content. Keep in mind, however, that it probably won’t work right away: it requires several additional (also open-source) components and references to, for example, include files use a format that will not function directly (XML catalogs are used). See the repository’s README file for more information.
The site is published using GitHub Pages.
If you find a bug or want to comment on the site’s contents, please use the GitHub issues mechanism and raise an issue.

This is an indication of the location where a component can be found in my storage/shed.

I’ve chosen to not state an exact price on the components. Commercial prices differ and change over time, so that would be unreliable and hard to keep up to date. Instead, I’ve categorized the components into price ranges. This gives you a rough idea of what they typically cost. I don’guarantee that the price range indications are correct.
